content.text: The unstretched length of the single spring is \(S_{1}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1
The unstretched length of the connected springs is \(S_{2}\), as shown in Fig. 1.2
Measure and record \(S_{1}\) and \(S_{2}\)
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.3
● Two string loops A and B are supporting the rule
Loop A should be placed 10.0 cm from one end of the rule
● The distance between the end of the rule and loop B is \(x\). Move loop B until \(x\) is approximately \(75 \text{cm}\)
● Measure and record \(x\)
x =
● Without changing the positions of the string loops, adjust the apparatus until the rule is parallel to the bench and the springs and the string loops are vertical
● The extended length of the single spring is \(L_{1}\)
The extended length of the connected springs is \(L_{2}\)
Measure and record \(L_{1}\) and \(L_{2}\)
Calculate \(e_1\) and \(e_2\), where
Vary \(x\) by changing the position of loop B. Loop B must remain on the right-hand side of the masses. Keep loop A in the same position

For each value of x, adjust the apparatus until the rule is parallel to the bench and the springs and the string loops are vertical. Measure x, \(L_{1}\) and \(L_{2}\). Repeat until you have five sets of values
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(e_1\), \(e_2\) and \(\frac{e_2}{e_1}\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(\frac{\Theta_2}{\Theta_1}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants
Using your answers in **(d)**(iii), determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\)
Give appropriate units
P =
Q =
The distance between string loop A and the centre of the rule is \(w\), as shown in Fig. 1.4
\(P\) and \(Q\) are each inversely proportional to \(w\)
A student repeats the experiment with loop A placed further from the left-hand end of the rule
Sketch a second line on the graph to show the expected results
Label this line W
In this experiment, you will investigate a balanced metre rule
You have been provided with three springs and a metre rule with masses attached to its centre
● Place the wooden strip on the pivot as shown in Fig. 2.1
● Adjust the position of the strip on the pivot until the strip balances
● The distance between G and the pivot is \(a\)
Without marking the strip, measure and record \(a\)
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2 with the nail through G
● Pull the bottom of the strip towards you through a short distance
● Release the strip. The strip will oscillate. The time for 10 oscillations is \(t\)
Measure and record \(t\)
● Set up the pendulum as shown in Fig. 2.3
● The distance between the bottom of the split cork and the centre of the bob is \(l\)
Adjust the position of the string in the split cork until \(l\) is approximately \(35 \text{cm}\)
● Pull the bob towards you through a short distance
● Release the bob. The bob will oscillate
● Adjust \(l\) until the time for 10 oscillations is the same as the value of \(t\) in **(b)**
● Measure and record \(l\)
l =
● Calculate \((l - a)\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \((l - a)\). Show your working
Using hole H, repeat (a)
a =
· Using hole H, repeat (b)
t =
· Using this value of \(t\), repeat (c)(i)
l =
Using your data, calculate two values of C
first value of C =
second value of C =
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of C
It is suggested that the relationship between \(l\) and \(a\) is
where \(C\) is a constant
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(C\) is \(5\%\)
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(e)**
Theory suggests that
where \(T\) is the period of the oscillations of the wooden strip and \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall
· Use your value of \(t\) from **(d)** to determine \(T\)
T =
· Use your value of \(a\) from **(d)** and the corresponding value of \(C\) to determine a value for \(g\). Give an appropriate unit
g =
Describe **four** sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
For any uncertainties in measurement that you describe, you should state the quantity being measured and a reason for the uncertainty
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**
In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillations of a wooden strip and a pendulum
You have been provided with a wooden strip with two holes G and H
Describe **four** improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
